nodes.bodyText: Good catch! I opened #708 to see about generating the -all artifact as part of assemble in the future, but good to update docs now to reflect the current state.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -86,10 +86,23 @@ snapshot builds of the `master` branch. They are available from
 
 Build using Java 11:
 
-```gradle assemble```
+```bash
+java -version
+```
+
+```bash
+./gradlew assemble
+```
+
+and then generate the -all artifact
+
+```bash
+./gradlew :opentelemetry-javaagent:shadowJar
+```

nodes.bodyText:
I like to set it globally, but maybe we should just recommend setting it locally

  
    
  
    

  
  This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -143,6 +156,12 @@ Our build will fail if source code is not formatted according to that style.
 The main goal is to avoid extensive reformatting caused by different IDEs having different opinion
 about how things should be formatted by establishing.
 
+For Windows users, please set autocrlf to true and line endings will be converted to Unix style line endings when adding files to the repo:
+
+```bash
+git config --global core.autocrlf true

nodes.bodyText:
This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            For Windows users, please set autocrlf to true and line endings will be converted to Unix style line endings when adding files to the repo:
          
          
            
            Note for Windows users: if you are seeing all of your files being changed by `./gradlew spotlessApply` (below), it's probably the line endings, and make sure you are using a `core.autocrlf` setting of either `true` or `input`.

nodes.bodyText:
@trask What do you think about adding .gitattributes with something like this?
* text=auto eol=lf

*.bat text eol=crlf
*.cmd text eol=crlf

I often develop on Windows, and I have only had pain with repositories without gitattributes and have never seen problems after adding it (modern OS / tools handle LF just fine on Windows too, even Notepad!).
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -143,6 +156,12 @@ Our build will fail if source code is not formatted according to that style.
 The main goal is to avoid extensive reformatting caused by different IDEs having different opinion
 about how things should be formatted by establishing.
 
+Note for Windows users: if you are seeing all of your files being changed by `./gradlew spotlessApply` (below), it's probably the line endings, and make sure you are using a `core.autocrlf` setting of either `true` or `input`.
+
+```bash
+git config core.autocrlf true

nodes.bodyText: oh, yes, that does work, as spotless respects the line endings in .gitattributes! (diffplug/spotless#23)
